properties.areaDesc: San Luis Obispo County Central Coast
properties.description:
The San Luis Obispo County Air Pollution Control District has issued
an air quality alert due to forecasted blowing dust and sand in
the Nipomo Mesa area. This air quality alert is in effect until 7 pm
PDT this evening.

Exposure to particle pollution can cause serious health problems...
aggravate lung disease...cause asthma attacks and acute bronchitis...
and increase risk of respiratory infections.

Residents are advised to use caution as conditions warrant. People
with heart or lung disease should follow their doctors advice for
dealing with episodes of blowing dust.

Additionally...older adults and children should avoid prolonged
exposure...strenuous activity or heavy exertion...as conditions
dictate.

For the latest air quality forecasts and information...visit the San
Luis Obispo County Air Pollution Control District website at
www.slocleanair.org. or call 805 781 5912
properties.headline: Air Quality Alert issued September 17 at 3:21PM PDT by NWS Los Angeles/Oxnard CA

properties.description:
The Shelby County Health Department has issued a Code Orange Ozone
Health Advisory effective for Shelby County Tennessee, Crittenden
County Arkansas, and DeSoto County Mississippi, including the city
of Memphis that will remain in effect until sunset. This ozone health
advisory is due to monitored ozone values that are unhealthy for
sensitive groups. These values have exceeded the Environmental
Protection Agency's federal safe health standard. The Shelby County
Health Department recommends that sensitive groups which include
active children and adults, and people with respiratory disease,
such as asthma, limit prolonged outdoor exertion. Please continue to
check the latest air quality forecasts and updates until monitored
values return to safe levels. For more information go to
www.midsouthcleanair.org.
properties.headline: Air Quality Alert issued September 17 at 4:55PM CDT by NWS Memphis TN

properties.areaDesc: Lake Pontchartrain and Lake Maurepas
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in New Orleans has issued a

* Special Marine Warning for...
Lake Pontchartrain and Lake Maurepas...

* Until 530 PM CDT.

* At 435 PM CDT, a severe thunderstorm producing waterspouts was
located 9 nm northwest of Kenner. The severe thunderstorm was
nearly stationary.

HAZARD...Waterspouts and wind gusts 34 knots or greater.

SOURCE...Radar.

IMPACT...Waterspouts can quickly form and capsize boats...damage
vessels and oil rigs...and create suddenly higher waves.
Make sure all on board are in a secure location and
wearing life jackets. Expect wind gusts in excess of 34
knots and suddenly higher waves. Boats could sustain
damage or capsize. Make sure all on board are wearing
life jackets. Return to safe harbor if possible.

Multiple reports of a waterspout have been reported.

* Locations impacted include...
Lake Maurepas.
properties.headline: Special Marine Warning issued September 17 at 4:36PM CDT until September 17 at 5:30PM CDT by NWS New Orleans LA

properties.description:
This product covers Southeast Texas

**TROPICAL STORM IMELDA PRODUCING HEAVY RAINFALL**

NEW INFORMATION
---------------

* CHANGES TO WATCHES AND WARNINGS:
- None

* CURRENT WATCHES AND WARNINGS:
- A Tropical Storm Warning is in effect for Brazoria Islands,
Coastal Brazoria, Coastal Galveston, Coastal Harris, and
Galveston Island and Bolivar Peninsula

* STORM INFORMATION:
- About 30 miles west of Galveston TX
- 29.3N 95.3W
- Storm Intensity 40 mph
- Movement North or 360 degrees at 7 mph

SITUATION OVERVIEW
------------------

Tropical Storm Imelda continues to move inland with the main threat being
heavy rainfall and flash flooding.

POTENTIAL IMPACTS
-----------------

* FLOODING RAIN:
Potential impacts from the flooding rain are still unfolding across
Southeast Texas. Remain well guarded against
life-threatening flood waters having possible extensive impacts. If realized,
these impacts include:
- Rivers and tributaries may rapidly overflow their banks in
multiple places. Small streams, creeks, canals, and ditches may
become dangerous rivers. Flood control systems and barriers may
become stressed.
- Streets and parking lots become rivers of water with
underpasses submerged. Driving conditions become dangerous.
Road closures.


* WIND:
Potential impacts from the main wind event are now unfolding across
coastal areas. If realized, these impacts include:
- Unsecured lightweight objects blown about.
- isolated power outages.

Elsewhere across Southeast Texas, little to no impact is anticipated.

* SURGE:
Little to no impacts are anticipated at this time across Southeast Texas.
Minor coastal flooding is possible along the immediate upper coast around
high tide times.

* TORNADOES:
Little to no impacts are anticipated at this time
across Southeast Texas.
properties.headline: Tropical Cyclone Statement issued September 17 at 4:32PM CDT by NWS Houston/Galveston TX
properties.instruction:
* OTHER PREPAREDNESS INFORMATION:

If you are prone to flooding be prepared for the possibility of a quick
rise in water levels.


* ADDITIONAL SOURCES OF INFORMATION:
- For information on appropriate preparations see ready.gov
- For information on creating an emergency plan see getagameplan.org
- For additional disaster preparedness information see redcross.org

NWSheadline: TROPICAL STORM IMELDA PRODUCING HEAVY RAINFALL

...Weather disturbance to bring gusty winds to parts of central
and eastern Nevada...

weather conditions to areas mainly south of US-50 in central and
east central Nevada Wednesday afternoon.

Warning for gusty winds and low relative humidity, which is in
effect from noon to 8 PM PDT Wednesday.

* Affected Area...Fire Weather Zone 455 White Pine County and
Fire Weather Zone 457 Northern Nye County/Lander and Eureka
Counties South of Highway 50.

* Winds...Southwest 15 to 20 mph with gusts up to 35 mph.

* Relative Humidity...As low as 12 percent.

* Impacts...The combination of gusty winds and low humidity will
create critical fire weather conditions.
properties.headline: Red Flag Warning issued September 17 at 2:09PM PDT until September 18 at 8:00PM PDT by NWS Elko NV
properties.instruction:
A red flag warning means that critical fire weather conditions
are either occurring now, or will shortly. A combination of
strong winds, low relative humidity, and warm temperatures can
contribute to extreme fire behavior.

...FLASH FLOOD WATCH IN EFFECT FROM THIS EVENING THROUGH THURSDAY
EVENING...

.Tropical moisture from Imelda will move across the region through
Thursday. Bands around the system may produce prolonged periods
of heavy rain which may quickly overwhelm drainage systems in
metro areas.

The National Weather Service in Lake Charles has issued a

* Flash Flood Watch for portions of southwest Louisiana and
southeast Texas, including the following areas, in southwest
Louisiana, Beauregard, Calcasieu, East Cameron, and West
Cameron. In southeast Texas, Hardin, Jefferson, Northern
Jasper, Northern Newton, Orange, Southern Jasper, Southern
Newton, and Tyler.

* From 7 PM CDT this evening through Thursday evening

* 2 to 6 inches of rainfall in far Southwest Louisiana with
isolated higher amounts. 4 to 9 inches of rain is forecast for
Southeast Texas with 12 inches or more possible in isolated
locations.

* Heavy rainfall in a short period of time may overwhelm drainage
systems causing flooding of streets and low lying areas.
properties.headline: Flash Flood Watch issued September 17 at 3:03PM CDT until September 19 at 7:00PM CDT by NWS Lake Charles LA
properties.instruction:

to flash flooding. Flash flooding is a VERY DANGEROUS SITUATION.

You should monitor later forecasts and be prepared to take action
should Flash Flood Warnings be issued.

properties.areaDesc: Jefferson; Shelby
properties.description:
The Alabama Department of Environmental Management, ADEM, has issued
an Air Quality Alert for Jefferson and Shelby Counties for
Wednesday, September 18.

Under Code Orange conditions, ground level ozone concentrations are
expected to reach levels that are unhealthy for sensitive groups.
Children and people with asthma are individuals most at risk under
these expected conditions.

ADEM recommends the following actions during an air quality alert
for ozone:

Conserve electricity and set your air conditioner at a higher
temperature.

Limit driving and combine errands.

Use the bus or car pool to work.

Avoid use of gasoline power lawn and garden equipment.

Refuel cars and trucks after 6 PM.

Limit engine idling.

Use household, workshop, and garden chemicals in ways that keep
evaporation to a minimum, or try to avoid them when poor air quality
is forecast.

If breathing becomes difficult, move indoors.

For more information on what to do on an air quality alert day,
visit the Environmental Protection Agency website at airnow.gov
properties.headline: Air Quality Alert issued September 17 at 2:43PM CDT by NWS Birmingham AL

NWSheadline: CODE ORANGE AIR QUALITY ALERT HAS BEEN ISSUED FOR JEFFERSON AND SHELBY COUNTIES

properties.areaDesc: Virginia Beach; Eastern Currituck
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Wakefield has issued a High Surf
Advisory, which is in effect from 7 AM Wednesday to 7 PM EDT
Thursday.

* LOCATION...Ocean side beaches from Maryland through Virginia
and northeast North Carolina.

* TIMING...For the High Surf Advisory, from 7 AM Wednesday to 7
PM EDT Thursday. For the Beach Hazards Statement, through
Wednesday evening. For the High Rip Current Risk, through
Wednesday evening.

* SHORELINE IMPACTS... Large breaking waves of 7 to 9 ft will
result in dangerous surf conditions. Do not enter or approach
the water due to the risk of being swept away.

* SURF OR RIP CURRENT RISK...There is a high risk of rip
currents.
properties.headline: High Surf Advisory issued September 17 at 3:32PM EDT until September 19 at 7:00PM EDT by NWS Wakefield VA
properties.instruction:
A High Surf Advisory means that high surf will affect beaches in
the advisory area...producing localized beach erosion and
dangerous swimming conditions.

A Beach Hazards Statement is issued when threats such as rip
currents...longshore currents...sneaker waves and other hazards
create life-threatening conditions in the surf zone. Caution
should be used when in or near the water.

There is a high risk of rip currents.

Rip currents are powerful channels of water flowing quickly away
from shore...which occur most often at low spots or breaks in the
sandbar and in the vicinity of structures such as jetties and
piers. Heed the advice of lifeguards...beach patrol flags and
signs.

If you become caught in a rip current...relax and float. Don't
swim against the current. If able, swim in a direction following
the shoreline. If unable to escape, face the shore and call or
wave for help.

NWSheadline: BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT NOW IN EFFECT THROUGH WEDNESDAY EVENING... ...HIGH RIP CURRENT RISK NOW IN EFFECT THROUGH WEDNESDAY EVENING... ...HIGH SURF ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 7 AM WEDNESDAY TO 7 PM EDT THURSDAY

properties.areaDesc: Coastal Palm Beach County
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Miami has issued a High Surf
Advisory, which is in effect until 8 PM EDT Saturday.

* WAVES AND SURF...Seas building to 10 to 12 feet off the palm
Beach Coast, with surf heights of 7 to 10 feet possible.

* TIMING...through at least Saturday evening.

* IMPACTS...Life threatening rip currents will pose a hazard to
swimmers. Heed the advice of lifeguards. Swimming is not
recommended. Dangerous conditions are expected at and around
jettys and inlets. Boaters should use extreme caution in these
areas.
properties.headline: High Surf Advisory issued September 17 at 3:26PM EDT until September 21 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Miami FL
properties.instruction:
There is a high risk of rip currents.

Rip currents are powerful channels of water flowing quickly away
from shore, which occur most often at low spots or breaks in the
sandbar and in the vicinity of structures such as groins, jetties
and piers. Heed the advice of lifeguards, beach patrol flags and
signs.

Swim near a lifeguard. If caught in a rip current, relax and
float. Don't swim against the current. If able, swim in a
direction following the shoreline. If unable to escape, face the
shore and call or wave for help.

A High Surf Advisory means that high surf will affect beaches in
the advisory area, producing localized beach erosion and
dangerous swimming conditions.

A sudden onset of rough seas may cause hazardous conditions, which
may occur suddenly at jettys and inlets. These conditions could
catch boaters by surprise. Boaters should use caution when
entering or exiting the inlets and jetty areas.

properties.headline: Rip Current Statement issued September 17 at 3:20PM EDT until September 18 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Upton NY
properties.instruction:
Rip currents are powerful channels of water flowing quickly away
from shore, which occur most often at low spots or breaks in
sandbars and near structures such as groins, jetties, and piers.
Talk to lifeguards and beach officials to learn about any surf
hazards and heed their advice. Pay attention to flags and posted
signs and swim in life guarded areas.

Swim near a lifeguard. If caught in a rip current, relax and
float, and do not swim against the current.  If able, swim in a
direction following the shoreline. If unable to escape, face the
shore and call or wave for help.

THE WATERS FOR MUCH OF THIS WEEK...

.Hurricane Humberto will pass well southeast of eastern North
Carolina the next several days. Large swells from Humberto and
strong northeast winds are expected as high pressure builds in
from the north. The large seas will persist into the weekend.

The National Weather Service in Newport/Morehead City has issued
a Gale Warning, which is in effect from 2 PM Wednesday to 1 AM
EDT Thursday. The Small Craft Advisory is no longer in effect.

* WINDS...Northeast 25 to 30 kt with frequent gusts 35 to 40 kt.

* SEAS...7 to 12 feet.

occurring. Operating a vessel in gale conditions requires
experience and properly equipped vessels. It is highly
recommended that mariners without the proper experience seek safe
harbor prior to the onset of gale conditions.

properties.description:
This product covers Southeast Texas

**TROPICAL DEPRESSION BECOMES TROPICAL STORM IMELDA NEAR THE TEXAS COAST**

NEW INFORMATION
---------------

* CHANGES TO WATCHES AND WARNINGS:
- None

* CURRENT WATCHES AND WARNINGS:
- A Tropical Storm Warning is in effect for Brazoria Islands,
Coastal Brazoria, Coastal Galveston, Coastal Harris, and
Galveston Island and Bolivar Peninsula

* STORM INFORMATION:
- Near Freeport TX
- 28.9N 95.3W
- Storm Intensity 35 mph
- Movement North or 5 degrees at 7 mph

SITUATION OVERVIEW
------------------

Tropical Storm Imelda is located near Freeport and is moving inland
this afternoon. The main threat remains heavy rainfall and flash
flooding.

POTENTIAL IMPACTS
-----------------

* FLOODING RAIN:
Protect against dangerous rainfall flooding having possible
significant impacts across the eastern portions of Southeast texas.
Potential impacts include:
- Rivers and tributaries may quickly become swollen with swifter
currents and overspill their banks in a few places, especially
in usually vulnerable spots. Small streams, creeks, canals, and
ditches overflow.
- Several places may experience inundation at underpasses, low-lying spots,
and poor drainage areas. Some streets and parking lots take on water
as storm drains and retention ponds overflow. Driving conditions
could become hazardous. Some road closures are possible.

* TORNADOES:
Little to no impacts are anticipated at this time
across Southeast Texas.

* WIND:
Limited impacts are possible across coastal areas. Potential impacts in
this area include:
- Unsecured lightweight objects blown about.


Elsewhere across Southeast Texas, little to no impact is anticipated.

* SURGE:
Little to no impacts are anticipated at this time
across Southeast Texas. Minor coastal flooding is possible along gulf facing
beaches around times of high tide.
properties.headline: Tropical Cyclone Statement issued September 17 at 1:18PM CDT by NWS Houston/Galveston TX
properties.instruction:
* OTHER PREPAREDNESS INFORMATION:

Never drive through a flooded roadway. Remember, turn around don't drown!

Closely monitor weather.gov, NOAA Weather radio or local news outlets
for official storm information. Be ready to adapt to possible changes
to the forecast. Ensure you have multiple ways to receive weather
warnings.


* ADDITIONAL SOURCES OF INFORMATION:
- For information on appropriate preparations see ready.gov
- For information on creating an emergency plan see getagameplan.org
- For additional disaster preparedness information see redcross.org

NWSheadline: TROPICAL DEPRESSION BECOMES TROPICAL STORM IMELDA NEAR THE TEXAS COAST

properties.areaDesc: Coastal waters from High Island to Freeport TX out 20 NM; Coastal waters from Freeport to Matagorda Ship Channel TX out 20 NM; Galveston Bay; Waters from High Island to Freeport TX from 20 to 60 NM
properties.description:
...TROPICAL STORM WARNING IN EFFECT...

.Tropical storm force wind will be possible over the coastal
waters of the Upper Texas Coast. Winds will increase wave heights
and support hazardous marine conditions.

The National Weather Service in Houston/Galveston has issued a
Tropical Storm Warning.

* WINDS...25 to 35 knots with gusts higher.

* WAVES/SEAS...6 to 9 feet.
properties.headline: Tropical Storm Warning issued September 17 at 12:51PM CDT by NWS Houston/Galveston TX
properties.instruction:
A Tropical Storm Warning means sustained winds of 34 to 63 kt or
39 to 73 mph or 63 to 118 km per hr are expected due to a
tropical cyclone within 36 hours.

NWSheadline: TROPICAL STORM WARNING IN EFFECT

properties.areaDesc: Coastal Brazoria
properties.description:
A Tropical Storm Warning means tropical storm-force winds are
expected somewhere within this area within the next 36 hours

* WIND
- LATEST LOCAL FORECAST: Below tropical storm force wind
- Peak Wind Forecast: 25-35 mph with gusts to 40 mph

- POTENTIAL THREAT TO LIFE AND PROPERTY: Potential for wind 39 to
57 mph
- PLAN: Plan for hazardous wind of equivalent tropical storm
force due to possible forecast changes in track, size, or
intensity.
- PREPARE: Efforts to protect property should now be
underway. Prepare for limited wind damage.
- ACT: Act now to complete preparations before the wind
becomes hazardous.

- POTENTIAL IMPACTS: Limited
- Damage to porches, awnings, carports, sheds, and unanchored
mobile homes. Unsecured lightweight objects blown about.
- Many large tree limbs broken off. A few trees snapped or
uprooted, but with greater numbers in places where trees
are shallow rooted. Some fences and roadway signs blown
over.
- A few roads impassable from debris, particularly within
urban or heavily wooded places. Hazardous driving
conditions on bridges and other elevated roadways.
- Scattered power and communications outages.

* STORM SURGE
- No storm surge inundation forecast

- POTENTIAL THREAT TO LIFE AND PROPERTY: Little to no storm surge
flooding
- PLAN: There is little to no threat of storm surge flooding.
Rough surf, coastal erosion, and life-threatening rip
currents are possible.
- PREPARE: Little to no preparations for storm surge flooding
are needed.
- ACT: Follow the instructions of local officials. Monitor
forecasts.

- POTENTIAL IMPACTS: Little to None
- Little to no potential impacts from storm surge flooding.

* FLOODING RAIN
- LATEST LOCAL FORECAST: Flash Flood Watch is in effect
- Peak Rainfall Amounts: Additional 6-10 inches, with locally
higher amounts

- POTENTIAL THREAT TO LIFE AND PROPERTY: Potential for moderate
flooding rain
- PLAN: Emergency plans should include the potential for
moderate flooding from heavy rain.
- PREPARE: Consider protective actions if you are in an area
vulnerable to flooding.
- ACT: Heed any flood watches and warnings.

- POTENTIAL IMPACTS: Significant
- Rivers and tributaries may quickly become swollen with
swifter currents and overspill their banks in a few places,
especially in usually vulnerable spots. Small streams,
creeks, canals, and ditches overflow.
- Several places may experience expanded areas
of rapid inundation at underpasses, low-lying spots, and
poor drainage areas. Some streets and parking lots take on
moving water as storm drains and retention ponds overflow.
Driving conditions become hazardous. Some road and bridge
closures.

* TORNADO
- LATEST LOCAL FORECAST:
- Situation is unfavorable for tornadoes

- POTENTIAL THREAT TO LIFE AND PROPERTY: Tornadoes not expected
- PLAN: Tornadoes are not expected. Showers and thunderstorms
with gusty winds may still occur.
- PREPARE: Little to no preparations needed to protect
against tornadoes at this time. Keep informed of the latest
tornado situation.
- ACT: Listen for changes in the forecast.

- POTENTIAL IMPACTS: Little to None
- Little to no potential impacts from tornadoes.

NWSheadline: TROPICAL STORM WARNING IN EFFECT

properties.areaDesc: Carlton/South St. Louis
properties.description:
At 1244 PM CDT, a strong thunderstorm was near Scanlon, or near
Cloquet, moving northeast at 25 mph.

Wind gusts up to 40 mph, half inch hail, torrential rainfall, and
frequent cloud to ground lightning can be expected with this storm.

Locations impacted include...
Duluth, Cloquet, Hermantown, Proctor, Scanlon, Carlton, Thomson,
Saginaw, Pike Lake Near Duluth, Fond Du Lac Reservation, City of Rice
Lake, Grand Lake, Mahnomen, Cody, Fish Lake, Central Hillside, Esko,
Piedmont Heights, Duluth Heights, and Lincoln Park.

Seek shelter inside a sturdy building and away from windows until
this storm passes. Torrential rainfall is occurring with this storm,
and may cause localized flooding. Do not drive into areas where
water covers the road, the road may be washed out.
properties.headline: Special Weather Statement issued September 17 at 12:44PM CDT by NWS Duluth MN

NWSheadline: A STRONG THUNDERSTORM WILL AFFECT SOUTH CENTRAL ST. LOUIS AND NORTHEASTERN CARLTON COUNTIES

properties.areaDesc: Southwest Big Horn Basin; Wind River Mountains East; Bighorn Mountains Southeast; Bighorn Mountains West; Wind River Basin; Lander Foothills; Southeast Big Horn Basin; Owl Creek and Bridger Mountains
properties.description:
This is a special weather statement from the National Weather
Service Office in Riverton.

* WHAT...West wind 20 to 30 mph with gusts of 35 to 45 mph. Gusts
up to 60 mph will occur over southern portions of the Absaroka
and Bighorn Mountains and the east slope of the Wind River
Mountains.

* WHERE...The Wind River Basin, southern portions of the Bighorn
Basin, the Absaroka, Bighorn and Wind river Mountains.

* WHEN...until 8 pm this evening.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Possible strong crosswinds could result in
a blowover risk for lightweight and high profile vehicles,
including camping and travel trailers. Residents are urged to
secure or bring indoors any loose items.
properties.headline: Special Weather Statement issued September 17 at 11:44AM MDT by NWS Riverton WY

NWSheadline: Strong Gusty Winds to impact central Wyoming Today

properties.areaDesc: Natrona County Lower Elevations; Green Mountains and Rattlesnake Range; East Sweetwater County; Casper Mountain
properties.description:
This is a special weather statement from the National Weather
Service Office in Riverton.

* WHAT...Southwest to west wind 25 to 35 mph with gusts of 40 to
50 mph. Gusts of 60+ mph expected over Outer Drive in Casper.

* WHERE...Eastern Sweetwater County to Natrona County.

* WHEN...Until 8 pm this evening..

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Possible strong crosswinds could result in
a blowover risk for lightweight and high profile vehicles,
including camping and travel trailers. Residents are urged to
secure or bring indoors any loose items.
properties.headline: Special Weather Statement issued September 17 at 11:44AM MDT by NWS Riverton WY

properties.description:

miles south of Powder River, which is 37 miles west of Casper, moving
northeast at 45 mph.

Wind gusts up to 50 mph will be possible with this storm.

This strong thunderstorm will be near...
Powder River around 1155 AM MDT.

Other locations impacted by this storm include Natrona and Arminto.

properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Baltimore MD/Washington has
issued a Small Craft Advisory, which is in effect from 11 AM
Wednesday to 8 AM EDT Thursday.

* WINDS...18 to 33 knots within the Small Craft Advisory.
properties.headline: Small Craft Advisory issued September 17 at 1:32PM EDT until September 19 at 8:00AM EDT by NWS Baltimore MD/Washington DC
properties.instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means winds of 18 to 33 knots are imminent
or occurring. Boaters operating smaller vessels should avoid
navigating in these conditions.

properties.description:

Thermopolis, moving north at 45 mph.

Lucerne around 1135 AM MDT.
Kirby around 1140 AM MDT.
Winchester around 1145 AM MDT.

properties.areaDesc: Duluth MN to Port Wing WI; Lake Superior west of a line from Saxon Harbor WI to Grand Portage MN beyond 5NM; Two Harbors to Duluth MN
properties.description:
The areas affected include...
Duluth MN to Port Wing WI...
Two Harbors to Duluth MN...

At 1221 PM CDT, Doppler radar indicated a strong thunderstorm,
capable of producing winds to around 30 knots, small hail, and
frequent cloud to water lightning. This strong thunderstorm was
located 27 nm southwest of Superior Harbor, or 29 nm southwest of
Duluth Lift Bridge Channel, moving northeast at 25 knots.

Locations impacted include...
Larsmont, Superior Harbor, Duluth Lift Bridge Channel, Brule Point,
French River, and Barkers Island.
properties.headline: Marine Weather Statement issued September 17 at 12:22PM CDT by NWS Duluth MN
properties.instruction:
Mariners can expect gusty winds to around 33 knots...locally higher
waves...and lightning strikes. Boaters should seek safe harbor
immediately until this storm passes.

NWSheadline: A STRONG THUNDERSTORM APPROACHING WESTERN LAKE SUPERIOR

properties.areaDesc: Southwest Carbon County
properties.description:
...STRONG WINDS EXPECTED ALONG INTERSTATE 80 FROM ARLINGTON TO
RAWLINS AND NORTHERN CARBON COUNTY ON HIGHWAY 287 NEAR MUDDY GAP
THROUGH THIS AFTERNOON...

The National Weather Service in Cheyenne has issued a High Wind
Warning, which is in effect until 6 PM MDT this evening.

* TIMING...Winds increasing this morning and continuing through
this afternoon.

* WINDS...West to southwest winds 30 to 40 mph sustained with
gusts to 60 mph.

* IMPACTS...Mainly to transportation. Light weight and high
profile vehicles may be blown off or blown over...especially
on north to south oriented roadways.
properties.headline: High Wind Warning issued September 17 at 11:11AM MDT until September 17 at 6:00PM MDT by NWS Cheyenne WY
properties.instruction:
A High Wind Warning means a hazardous high wind event is expected
or occurring. Sustained wind speeds of at least 40 mph or gusts
of 58 mph or more can lead to property damage.

NWSheadline: HIGH WIND WARNING IN EFFECT UNTIL 6 PM MDT THIS EVENING

properties.areaDesc: Green Mountains and Rattlesnake Range
properties.description:
At 1056 AM MDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm 7
miles south of Crooks Gap, which is 14 miles south of Jeffrey City,
moving northeast at 40 mph.

Pea size hail and wind gusts up to 50 mph will be possible with this
storm.

This strong thunderstorm will be near...
Crooks Gap around 1100 AM MDT.
Green Mountain around 1110 AM MDT.
Split Rock around 1125 AM MDT.
properties.headline: Special Weather Statement issued September 17 at 10:57AM MDT by NWS Riverton WY
properties.instruction:
To report severe weather, contact your nearest law enforcement
agency. They will relay your report to the National Weather Service
office in Riverton.

NWSheadline: SIGNIFICANT WEATHER ADVISORY FOR SOUTHWESTERN NATRONA... SOUTHEASTERN FREMONT AND NORTHEASTERN SWEETWATER COUNTIES UNTIL 1130 AM MDT

properties.areaDesc: Southwest Big Horn Basin; Wind River Basin; Southeast Big Horn Basin; Owl Creek and Bridger Mountains
properties.description:
At 1054 AM MDT, Doppler radar was tracking strong thunderstorms along
a line extending from 15 miles north of Pavillion to 6 miles east of
Hidden Valley. Movement was northeast at 50 mph.

Wind gusts up to 50 mph will be possible with these storms.

Strong thunderstorms will be near...
Hamilton Dome and Legend Rock State Petroglyph Site around 1120 AM
MDT.

Other locations impacted by these storms include Bonneville, Badlands
Overlook, Hot Springs County Airport and Hot Springs County
Fairgrounds.
properties.headline: Special Weather Statement issued September 17 at 10:55AM MDT by NWS Riverton WY
properties.instruction:
To report severe weather, contact your nearest law enforcement
agency. They will relay your report to the National Weather Service
office in Riverton.

If on or near Boysen Reservoir, get out of the water and move
indoors or inside a vehicle. Remember, lightning can strike out to
10 miles from the parent thunderstorm. If you can hear thunder, you
are close enough to be struck by lightning. Move to safe shelter
now! Do not be caught on the water in a thunderstorm.

NWSheadline: SIGNIFICANT WEATHER ADVISORY FOR HOT SPRINGS...EAST CENTRAL FREMONT AND CENTRAL WASHAKIE COUNTIES UNTIL 1130 AM MDT

A las 9:35 AM AST...el radar Doppler detecto tronadas fuerte,
capaces de producir vientos a alrededor de 30 nudos. Estas tronadas
estaban localizada al sur del Pasaje de la Mona y las aguas mar
afuera del caribe al suroeste de Puerto rico. Esta tronada esta
moviendose al oeste a 20 nudos.

nudos, oleaje mas alto localmente y rayos. Los operadores de
embarcaciones pequenas deben buscar puerto seguro inmediatamente
hasta que pasen las tronadas.

encuentra sobre aguas abiertas, mantengase bajo cubierta y alejese
de objetos de metal.

properties.description:
Patchy dense fog will continue in many river valleys this morning
across eastern New York and adjacent western New England.

Portions of the Mohawk and Hudson Valleys, the Schoharie Valley,
and Housatonic and Connecticut River Valleys in southern Vermont,
Massachusetts and northwest Connecticut will be most prone to this
patchy dense fog.

In some of these areas, visibilities may drop below one half of a
mile. Motorists are urged to use extra caution this morning, use
low beam headlights and allow for increased breaking distance when
traveling through these areas.

The fog is expected to lift between 8 and 10 AM.
properties.headline: Special Weather Statement issued September 17 at 5:31AM EDT by NWS Albany NY

properties.areaDesc: Waushara; Northern Marinette County; Waupaca; Southern Oconto County; Northern Oconto County; Manitowoc; Forest; Outagamie; Calumet; Florence; Door; Menominee; Langlade; Winnebago; Shawano; Brown; Southern Marinette County; Kewaunee
properties.description:
Dense fog continued to reduce the visibility to less than a
quarter of mile at times over far eastern Wisconsin early this
morning. The worst conditions were near Lake Michigan and the Bay
of Green Bay, where the visibility was below 1/4 mile at times.
Farther west, the visibility was fluctuating more, and generally
not dropping as low as near the bay and lake.

Although conditions away from the lake and bay were not as
favorable for dense fog as farther east, the persistent dense fog
may still edge a bit farther west around sunrise.

Motorists traveling near Lake Michigan, especially on Interstate
43 between Green Bay and Manitowoc, and on Highway 42 and Highway
57, should anticipate fluctuations in the visibility due to the
dense fog. Poor conditions are also likely on Highway 41 between
Green Bay and Marinette. If you encounter dense fog, slow down,
keep a safe distance from the car ahead of you, and use your low
beam headlights.

Conditions should begin to improve across the entire area by mid-
morning.
properties.headline: Special Weather Statement issued September 17 at 4:23AM CDT by NWS Green Bay WI

NWSheadline: DENSE FOG WILL IMPACT TRAVEL OVER PORTIONS OF EASTERN WISCONSIN THIS MORNING

properties.areaDesc: Galveston Island and Bolivar Peninsula; Inland Harris; Coastal Galveston; Brazoria Islands; Chambers; Inland Matagorda; Coastal Matagorda; Southern Liberty; Coastal Harris; Coastal Brazoria; Northern Liberty; Inland Brazoria; Matagorda Islands; Fort Bend; Wharton; Inland Galveston
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Houston/Galveston has issued a

* Flash Flood Watch for a portion of southeast Texas...including
the following counties...Brazoria Islands...Chambers...Coastal
Brazoria...Coastal Galveston...Coastal Harris...Coastal
Matagorda...Fort Bend...Galveston Island and Bolivar
Peninsula...Inland Brazoria...Inland Galveston...Inland
Harris...Inland Matagorda...Matagorda Islands...Northern
Liberty...Southern Liberty and Wharton.

* From 1 PM CDT this afternoon through Wednesday afternoon

* A weak coastal trough coupled with an upper level low and deep
tropical moisture will will produce periods of showers and
thunderstorms today. Some of the rain will be locally heavy
especially along and south of a Wharton to Houston to Cleveland
line. Widespread rainfall by Wednesday morning will average
between 1 and 3 inches with isolated totals between 4 and 6
inches possible in areas where training of storms develop.

* The Flash Flood Watch will probably need to be extended through
Wednesday night over parts of Southeast Texas and may also need
to be expanded further north.

* Do not drive your vehicle into areas where the water covers the
roadway. The water depth may be too great to allow your car to
cross safely. Vehicles caught in rising water should be
abandoned quickly. If your vehicle stalls...abandon it and seek
higher ground immediately. Rapidly rising water may engulf your
vehicle and its occupants and sweep them away. Move to higher
ground.
properties.headline: Flash Flood Watch issued September 17 at 4:14AM CDT until September 18 at 1:00PM CDT by NWS Houston/Galveston TX
properties.instruction:
A Flash Flood Watch means that conditions may develop that lead
to flash flooding. Flash flooding is a very dangerous situation.

Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize
the dangers of floods and flash floods. If flash flooding is
observed...act quickly. Move up to escape flood waters. Do not
stay in areas subject to flooding when water begins rising.

You should monitor later forecasts and be prepared to take action
should Flash Flood Warnings be issued.

NWSheadline: FLASH FLOOD WATCH IN EFFECT FROM 1 PM CDT THIS AFTERNOON THROUGH WEDNESDAY AFTERNOON

.Tide level running 1 to 1.5 feet above normal this afternoon

barrier islands. Minor coastal flooding is possible in lower areas
around Bays through this evening. Water levels generally less than
1 foot above ground level (around 2 ft MSL) are expected.

Coastal Flood Advisory, which is in effect from 4 PM this
afternoon to 10 PM CDT this evening.

the dunes on North Padre Island, Mustang Island, and in coastal
flood prone areas along Bays during high astronomical tides.

* TIMING...Through 10PM this evening

* IMPACTS...Poor driving conditions are expected as water reaches
the dunes, mainly during high tide cycle. Some beach access
roads will be impassable.

properties.description:
...HIGH RISK OF DANGEROUS RIP CURRENTS TODAY...

The National Weather Service in Melbourne has issued a High Rip
Current Risk, which is in effect from 7 AM EDT this morning through
this evening.

* TIMING...While potential life-threatening rip currents will be
present all day, the risk will be highest from 7 AM this morning
through 1 PM this afternoon, and again after 7 PM this evening.

* IMPACTS...Numerous strong rip currents and 4 to 6 foot breaking
waves in the surf zone will post a threat to swimmers today.
The long shore current will also make swimming hazardous to
everyone, regardless of experience. Swimmers may not to enter
the water above their knees today.
properties.headline: Rip Current Statement issued September 17 at 4:04AM EDT until September 17 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Melbourne FL
properties.instruction:
Heed the advice of lifeguards...beach patrol flags and signs.

Swim near a lifeguard. If caught in a rip current, relax and
float. Don't swim against the current. If able, swim in a
direction following the shoreline. If unable to escape, face the
shore and call or wave for help.

NWSheadline: HIGH RIP CURRENT RISK IN EFFECT THROUGH THIS EVENING

FROM CAPE LOOKOUT NORTH...

.The combination of easterly and southeasterly swell will produce
dangerous rip currents, shorebreak, and strong longshore currents
along area beaches today. Building seas tonight will lead to high
surf conditions for the beaches from Cape Lookout north that will
continue through the end of the week.

The National Weather Service in Newport/Morehead City has issued
a High Surf Advisory, which is in effect from 11 PM this evening
to 8 PM EDT Friday.

* HAZARDS...High risk for dangerous rip currents, dangerous
shorebreak, and strong longshore currents.

* LOCATIONS...Beaches from Cape Lookout north.

* TIMING...For the High Surf Advisory, from 11 PM this evening
to 8 PM EDT Friday. For the Beach Hazards Statement, through
this evening.

* TIMING AND TIDES...The most likely time for strong rip currents
to develop are a couple of hours before and after low tide,
which will occur around 4 PM this afternoon.

* SURF HEIGHT...Building to 6 to 8 feet tonight and peaking 8 to
11 feet Wednesday night through early Friday.

* SHORELINE IMPACTS...The rough surf will lead to beach erosion
with threat of localized ocean overwash during high tide.
properties.headline: High Surf Advisory issued September 17 at 3:02AM EDT until September 20 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Newport/Morehead City NC
properties.instruction:
A High Surf Advisory means that high surf will affect beaches in
the advisory area, producing localized beach erosion and
dangerous swimming conditions.

If caught in a rip current remain calm. Don't fight the current.
Swim in a direction following the shoreline. When out of the
current, swim back to shore. If tired, float or tread water until
out of the rip current. If unable to escape, face the shore and
call or wave for help.

Strong longshore currents can sweep swimmers and surfers into rip
currents, piers, jetties and other hazardous areas. In many cases
the longshore current is strong enough to prevent swimmers from
being able to keep their feet on the bottom making it difficult
to return to shore.

FROM CAPE LOOKOUT NORTH...

.The combination of easterly and southeasterly swell will produce
dangerous rip currents, shorebreak, and strong longshore currents
along area beaches today. Building seas tonight will lead to high
surf conditions for the beaches from Cape Lookout north that will

shorebreak, and strong longshore currents.

* LOCATIONS...Beaches south of Cape Lookout.

* SURF HEIGHT...Dangerous shore break of 3 to 5 feet.
properties.headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued September 17 at 3:02AM EDT until September 17 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Newport/Morehead City NC
properties.instruction:
If caught in a rip current remain calm. Don't fight the current.
Swim in a direction following the shoreline. When out of the
current, swim back to shore. If tired, float or tread water until
out of the rip current. If unable to escape, face the shore and
call or wave for help.

Shore break occurs when waves break directly on the beach. The
most common injuries with strong shore break are neck and back
injuries, which most often occur when the powerful surf throws a
swimmer or surfer head first into the bottom. It is extremely
important to protect your head and neck whenever you are in
breaking waves by keeping your hands in front of you at all
times.

Strong longshore currents can sweep swimmers and surfers into rip
currents, piers, jetties and other hazardous areas. In many cases
the longshore current is strong enough to prevent swimmers from
being able to keep their feet on the bottom making it difficult
to return to shore.

properties.description:

Current Risk, which is in effect through Friday evening.

* TIMING...through at least Friday evening.

* IMPACTS...Life threatening rip currents will pose a hazard to
swimmers. Heed the advice of lifeguards. Swimming is not
recommended.
properties.headline: Rip Current Statement issued September 17 at 2:58AM EDT until September 20 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Miami FL
properties.instruction:
There is a high risk of rip currents.

Rip currents are powerful channels of water flowing quickly away
from shore, which occur most often at low spots or breaks in the
sandbar and in the vicinity of structures such as groins, jetties
and piers. Heed the advice of lifeguards, beach patrol flags and
signs.

Swim near a lifeguard. If caught in a rip current, relax and
float. Don't swim against the current. If able, swim in a
direction following the shoreline. If unable to escape, face the
shore and call or wave for help.

NWSheadline: HIGH RIP CURRENT RISK IN EFFECT THROUGH FRIDAY EVENING

properties.description:
A very wet period is expected with the potential for multiple
atmospheric river events to impact southeast Alaska. The first
event is expected to occur Wednesday into early Thursday with a
second more significant event expected to occur Friday and
Saturday. There is potential for yet another event early next
week. Exact timing and precipitation amounts remain uncertain;
however, the Northeast Gulf Coast is currently the most favored
area for highest precipitation totals. In all of these events,
rainfall has the potential to reach multi inch daily totals. The
potential also exists for significant rises to occur along small
streams and water basins, so continue to monitor the latest
forecasts and statements.
properties.headline: Hydrologic Outlook issued September 16 at 9:33PM AKDT by NWS Juneau AK

properties.areaDesc: Coastal Pender; Coastal Horry; Coastal New Hanover; Coastal Brunswick; Coastal Georgetown
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Wilmington has issued a Beach
Hazards Statement, which is in effect from 8 AM EDT Tuesday
through Tuesday evening. A High Rip Current Risk has also been
issued. This High Rip Current Risk is in effect from 8 AM EDT
Tuesday through Tuesday evening.

* LOCATIONS...In South Carolina, Coastal Horry and Coastal
Georgetown. In North Carolina, Coastal Pender, Coastal New
Hanover and Coastal Brunswick.

* TIMING...From 8 AM EDT Tuesday through Tuesday evening.

* SURF ZONE IMPACTS...Very strong rip currents will be dangerous
to anyone who enters the surf. Additionally, northeasterly winds
15-25 mph will produce a strong left to right longshore current
at all of our area beaches.
properties.headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued September 16 at 8:04PM EDT until September 17 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Wilmington NC
properties.instruction:
A Beach Hazards Statement is issued when threats such as rip
currents, longshore currents, and other hazards create life-
threatening conditions in the surf zone. Caution should be used
when in or near the water.

There is a high risk of rip currents. Life threatening rip
currents are likely in the surf zone.

Rip currents are powerful channels of water flowing quickly away
from shore, which occur most often at low spots or breaks in the
sandbar and in the vicinity of structures such as groins, jetties
and piers. Heed the advice of lifeguards, beach patrol flags and
signs.

If you become caught in a rip current, yell for help. Remain
calm, do not exhaust yourself and stay afloat while waiting for
help. If you have to swim out of a rip current, swim parallel to
shore and back toward the beach when possible. Do not attempt to
swim directly against a rip current as you will tire quickly.

NWSheadline: BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT IN EFFECT FROM 8 AM EDT TUESDAY THROUGH TUESDAY EVENING... ...HIGH RIP CURRENT RISK IN EFFECT FROM 8 AM EDT TUESDAY THROUGH TUESDAY EVENING

headlights.

properties.instruction:
A Gale Warning means winds of 34 to 47 knots are imminent or
occurring. Operating a vessel in gale conditions requires
experience and properly equipped vessels. It is highly
recommended that mariners without the proper experience seek safe
harbor prior to the onset of gale conditions.

A Hazardous Seas Warning means very steep and hazardous sea
conditions are imminent or occurring. Recreational boaters should
remain in port, or take shelter until waves subside.  Commercial
vessels should prepare for rough seas and consider remaining in
port or taking shelter in port until hazardous seas subside.

A Small Craft Advisory means that winds and seas will create a
potential hazard to smaller vessels and inexperienced mariners.

properties.description:
...Strong Rip Currents and Minor Beach Flooding will be possible
through Tuesday Morning...

.A Beach Hazards Statement has been issued to combine both the Rip
Current Statement and Coastal Flood Statement. Strong easterly winds
will induce strong rip currents and minor coastal flooding during times
of high tide through at least Tuesday morning. This statement may need
to be extended as elevated tide levels are expected to persist through
mid week.

...High Rip Current Risk and Possible Coastal Flooding...

* HAZARDS...Elevated tide levels resulting in the risk for coastal flooding.

* Timing...Through at least Tuesday morning.

* LOCATION...Along Gulf facing beaches.

* POTENTIAL IMPACTS...Strong rip currents along Gulf facing beaches and
minor flooding along flood prone roads may be possible along
Highway 87 near High Island and Blue Water Highway.
properties.headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued September 16 at 4:03PM CDT until September 17 at 7:00AM CDT by NWS Houston/Galveston TX
properties.instruction:
There is a high risk of rip currents. Life threatening rip
currents are likely in the surf zone.

Rip currents are powerful channels of water flowing quickly away
from shore...which occur most often at low spots or breaks in the
sandbar and in the vicinity of structures such as groins...
jetties and piers. Heed the advice of lifeguards...beach patrol...
flags and signs. Swim near a lifeguard.

Driving vehicles on flooded beaches and roadways is discouraged.


A Beach Hazards Statement is issued when threats such as rip
currents...longshore currents...sneaker waves and other hazards
create life-threatening conditions in the surf zone. Caution
should be used when in or near the water.

barrier islands. Minor coastal flooding is possible in lower areas
around Bays as well through this evening. Water levels generally
less than 1 foot above ground level (around 2ft MSL) are
expected.

Coastal Flood Advisory, which is in effect until 10 PM CDT this
evening.

the dunes on North Padre Island, Mustang Island and in coastal
flood prone areas along bays during high astronomical tides.

* IMPACTS...Poor driving conditions are expected as water reaches
the dunes, mainly during high tide cycle. Some beach access
roads will be impassible.

properties.areaDesc: Northwest
properties.description:
A strong low in the northern Atlantic has sent large swell toward
the local area. Later this week Hurricane Humberto will also add
swell across the area. This will create a high risk of rip
currents and high surf with breaking waves of 10 feet and
greater.

The National Weather Service in SAN JUAN has issued a High Surf
Advisory, which is in effect from 6 AM Tuesday to 6 AM AST
Wednesday. A High Rip Current Risk has also been issued. This
High Rip Current Risk is in effect through late Thursday night.

* WAVES AND SURF...Seas up to 8 feet breaking waves up to 13
feet.

* LOCATION...the Northwest beaches of Puerto Rico.

* TIMING...High surf from 6 AM AST Tuesday morning through 6 AM
AST Wednesday. High rip current risk until at least Friday.

* IMPACTS...Strong currents that can carry even the strongest of
swimmers out to sea. Large breaking waves that can knock persons
and animals off of rocks and jetties and into the sea and cause
coastal erosion.
properties.headline: Rip Current Statement issued September 16 at 3:28PM AST until September 20 at 6:00AM AST by NWS San Juan PR
properties.instruction:
There is a high risk of rip currents.

Swim near a lifeguard. If caught in a rip current, relax and
float. Don't swim against the current. If able, swim in a
direction following the shoreline. If unable to escape, face the
shore and call or wave for help.

A High Surf Advisory means that high surf will affect beaches in
the advisory area...producing localized beach erosion and
dangerous swimming conditions.

properties.instruction:

float. Don't swim against the current. If able, swim in a
direction following the shoreline. If unable to escape, face the
shore and call or wave for help.

properties.headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued September 16 at 4:25PM EDT until September 17 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Wakefield VA
properties.instruction:
A Beach Hazards Statement is issued when threats such as rip
currents...longshore currents...sneaker waves and other hazards
create life-threatening conditions in the surf zone. Caution
should be used when in or near the water.

There is a high risk of rip currents.

Rip currents are powerful channels of water flowing quickly away
from shore...which occur most often at low spots or breaks in the
sandbar and in the vicinity of structures such as jetties and
piers. Heed the advice of lifeguards...beach patrol flags and
signs.

If you become caught in a rip current...relax and float. Don't
swim against the current. If able, swim in a direction following
the shoreline. If unable to escape, face the shore and call or
wave for help.

properties.areaDesc: Jefferson; Shelby
properties.description:
The Alabama Department of Environmental Management, ADEM, has issued
an Air Quality Alert for Jefferson and Shelby Counties for Tuesday,
September 17.

Under Code Orange conditions, ground level ozone concentrations are
expected to reach levels that are unhealthy for sensitive groups.
Children and people with asthma are individuals most at risk under
these expected conditions.

ADEM recommends the following actions during an air quality alert
for ozone:

Conserve electricity and set your air conditioner at a higher
temperature.

Limit driving and combine errands.

Use the bus or car pool to work.

Avoid use of gasoline power lawn and garden equipment.

Refuel cars and trucks after 6 PM.

Limit engine idling.

Use household, workshop, and garden chemicals in ways that keep
evaporation to a minimum, or try to avoid them when poor air quality
is forecast.

If breathing becomes difficult, move indoors.

For more information on what to do on an air quality alert day,
visit the Environmental Protection Agency website at airnow.gov
properties.headline: Air Quality Alert issued September 16 at 1:45PM CDT by NWS Birmingham AL

properties.areaDesc: Acadia; St. Mary; Lower St. Martin; Vermilion; Orange; East Cameron; Iberia; Calcasieu; Jefferson Davis; Jefferson; West Cameron; Upper St. Martin; Lafayette
properties.description:
At 1215...The National Weather Service has received a
report of multiple funnel clouds in the vicinity of Johnsons
Bayou.

A very moist and unstable tropical airmass is in place across
the area. Meanwhile...the vertical wind profile over the area
is light and variable. These conditions are favorable for the
development of tropical funnel clouds...especially where rain
cooled boundaries...known as outflow boundaries...and the
seabreeze collide.

These tropical funnel clouds are usually short-lived and do not
reach the ground. If the funnel cloud becomes more severe and
reaches the ground...minor damage may occur...and a tornado
warning will likely be issued.

Stay tuned for later statements and updates on this weather
situation.
properties.headline: Special Weather Statement issued September 16 at 12:28PM CDT by NWS Lake Charles LA

NWSheadline: TROPICAL FUNNEL CLOUD SIGHTED

properties.areaDesc: Holt, NE
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in North Platte has issued a

* Flood Advisory for...
Central Holt County in north central Nebraska...

* Until 1215 AM CDT Wednesday.

* The Elkhorn River through Holt county continues to run bankfull or
above flood stage in places. The river has fallen below the flood
stage of 9.0 feet at Ewing with a current reading of 8.5 feet.
However, upstream at Atkinson, the river is still above the flood
stage of 7.5 feet with a current reading of 8.5 feet. Many roads
continue to have water across them, and likely will for some time.

* Some locations that will experience flooding include...
O'Neill, Atkinson, Stuart, Ewing, Page, Inman and Emmet.

This includes the following highways...
Highway 20 between mile markers 275 and 328.
Highway 281 between mile markers 168 and 189.
properties.headline: Flood Advisory issued September 16 at 12:27PM CDT until September 18 at 12:15AM CDT by NWS North Platte NE

hasta 10 MN-
Caribbean Waters of Puerto Rico
1053 AM AST lunes 16 de septiembre de 2019

...SE ESPERAN AGUACEROS Y TRONADAS AFECTANDO SECTORES DE LAS AGUAS
REGINOALES DURANTE LAS PROXIMAS HORAS...

Se espera una onda tropical moviendose a traves del area que
produzca ronda de aguaceros y tronadas con rayos frecuentes, vientos
en rafagas hasta 30 nudos, y lluvias fuertes. Se espera que la
actividad mas fuertes sobre las aguas del Caribe y pasaje Anegada
hasta esta tarde.

MEDIDAS DE PRECAUCION/PREPARATIVOS...

Los navegantes pueden esperar vientos en rafagas alrededor de 30
nudos, oleaje mas alto localmente y rayos. Los operadores de
embarcaciones pequenas deben buscar puerto seguro inmediatamente
hasta que pasen las tronadas.

Manteganse altera a los communicados o posible vigilancias y avisos
del officina del Servicio Nacional de Meteorologia en San Juan.

properties.description:
The South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control in
Columbia SC has issued a Code Orange Ground Level Ozone Action Day
for the Upstate and Catawba regions of South Carolina, until 8 PM
EDT this evening.

An ozone action day means that atmospheric conditions will likely
produce unhealthy concentrations of ground level ozone air
pollution. A Code Orange forecast indicates that ground level ozone
concentrations are expected to be unhealthy for sensitive groups,
which includes people with lung disease, older adults and children.
Sensitive groups should reduce prolonged or heavy outdoor exertion,
take more breaks, and do less intense activities, especially during
afternoon and early evening hours. You can help prevent ozone
pollution by carpooling, walking or riding your bicycle, taking your
lunch to work, reducing idling, conserving energy, and keeping your
vehicle properly tuned. For additional information, please visit the
South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control web
site at http://www.scdhec.gov/ozone or the Environmental Protection
Agency AirNow website at https://www.airnow.gov.
properties.headline: Air Quality Alert issued September 16 at 10:25AM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg SC

* Flood advisory for...
The island of Kauai in Kauai County

* Until 415 AM HST.

interior and northern sections of Kauai. Rain is falling at a rate
of 1 to 2 inches per hour. The Wainiha and Hanalei streams have

Park and Wailua Homesteads.

flooding.

Do not cross fast flowing or rising water in your vehicle, or on
foot. Turn around, don't drown.

eastern Iowa and northwest Illinois into the mid morning. The fog

visibilities.

Fog Advisory, which is in effect until 10 AM CDT this morning.

less, creating hazardous travel conditions.

.Light winds and clear skies have allowed areas of dense fog to
develop over eastern Wisconsin overnight. Light northwest winds
have carried the dense fog over the nearshore waters early this
morning. The dense fog is causing visibilities of 1 mile or less,
and should continue through mid-morning.

The National Weather Service in Milwaukee/Sullivan has issued a
Dense Fog Advisory...which is in effect until 10 AM CDT this
morning.

* VISIBILITY: Areas of dense fog causing 1 mile or less
visibilities.
properties.headline: Dense Fog Advisory issued September 16 at 5:51AM CDT until September 16 at 10:00AM CDT by NWS Milwaukee/Sullivan WI
properties.instruction:
A Dense Fog Advisory means visibilities will frequently be
reduced to less than one mile. Inexperienced mariners...
especially those operating smaller vessels should avoid
navigating in these conditions.

NWSheadline: DENSE FOG ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 10 AM CDT THIS MORNING

properties.areaDesc: Mono
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Reno has issued a Wind Advisory,
which is in effect from 11 AM this morning to 8 PM PDT this
evening.

* Timing: Strong and gusty winds expected by mid-morning and
continuing through the afternoon.

* Winds: Southwest winds 15 to 30 mph with gusts 45 to 50 mph.
Wind prone locations along the Highway 395 corridor may see
gusts up to 60 mph.

* Impacts: Strong crosswinds possible along the Highway 395
corridor. Roads may be closed to high profile vehicles at
times.
properties.headline: Wind Advisory issued September 16 at 3:48AM PDT until September 16 at 8:00PM PDT by NWS Reno NV
properties.instruction:
Secure loose outdoor items such as patio furniture, holiday
decorations, and trash cans which could be blown away. Have extra
food and water on hand, flashlights with spare batteries and/or
candles in the event of a power outage.

NWSheadline: WIND ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 11 AM THIS MORNING TO 8 PM PDT THIS EVENING

properties.areaDesc: Waters from Okaloosa-Walton County Line to Pensacola FL from 20 to 60 NM; Waters from Pensacola FL to Pascagoula MS from 20 to 60 NM
properties.description:
At 539 AM CDT...A line of strong thunderstorms was located along a
line extending from 24 nm south of Okaloosa Deep Water Reef to 34 nm
south of Farewell Buoy...moving north northwest at 15 knots.

These storms will remain over mainly open waters.

The primary threats from these storms are wind gusts up to 30
knots...locally higher waves...and heavy downpours. Boaters should
consider seeking safe harbor until these storms have passed.

Frequent lightning is occurring with some of these storms.  If
caught on the open water stay below deck if possible and keep away
from metal objects.

Weather conditions support the development of waterspouts.
Waterspouts can easily overturn boats and create locally hazardous
waves and seas.
properties.headline: Marine Weather Statement issued September 16 at 5:42AM CDT by NWS Mobile AL

NWSheadline: A line of strong thunderstorms will affect Waters from Okaloosa-Walton County Line to Pensacola FL from 20 to 60 NM... Waters from Pensacola FL to Pascagoula MS from 20 to 60 NM... Until 645 AM CDT.

properties.areaDesc: Coastal Matagorda; Coastal Jackson; Coastal Harris; Coastal Brazoria; Coastal Galveston; Chambers
properties.description:
...Strong Rips Currents and Minor Beach Flooding through Tuesday
Morning...

.Strong easterly winds will induce strong rip currents and minor
coastal flooding during times of high tide.

* COASTAL FLOODING...Low lying areas along the immediate coast
may experience minor coastal flooding during high tide times.

* TIMING...Through Tuesday morning.

* IMPACTS...Minor flooding along flood prone roads such as
Seabrook road. Other roads near the shore may also be at risk
during times of high tide.
properties.headline: Coastal Flood Statement issued September 16 at 5:41AM CDT until September 17 at 7:00AM CDT by NWS Houston/Galveston TX
properties.instruction: Driving vehicles on flooded beaches and roadways is discouraged.

NWSheadline: COASTAL FLOODING POSSIBLE THROUGH TUESDAY MORNING

properties.areaDesc: Galveston Island and Bolivar Peninsula; Matagorda Islands; Brazoria Islands
properties.description:
...Strong Rips Currents and Minor Beach Flooding through Tuesday
Morning...

.Strong easterly winds will induce strong rip currents and minor
coastal flooding during times of high tide.

...COASTAL FLOODING POSSIBLE THROUGH TUESDAY MORNING...

* COASTAL FLOODING...Low lying areas along the immediate coast
may experience minor coastal flooding during high tide times.

* TIMING...Through Tuesday morning.

* IMPACTS...Strong rip currents along Gulf facing beaches and
minor flooding along flood prone roads may be possible along
Highway 87 near High Island and Blue Water Highway.
properties.headline: Coastal Flood Statement issued September 16 at 5:41AM CDT until September 17 at 7:00AM CDT by NWS Houston/Galveston TX
properties.instruction:
There is a high risk of rip currents. Life threatening rip
currents are likely in the surf zone.

Rip currents are powerful channels of water flowing quickly away
from shore...which occur most often at low spots or breaks in the
sandbar and in the vicinity of structures such as groins...
jetties and piers. Heed the advice of lifeguards...beach patrol...
flags and signs. Swim near a lifeguard.

If you become caught in a rip current...yell for help. Remain
calm...do not exhaust yourself and stay afloat while waiting for
help. If you have to swim out of a rip current...swim parallel to
shore and back toward the beach when possible. Do not attempt to
swim directly against a rip current as you will tire quickly.

Driving vehicles on flooded beaches and roadways is discouraged.

NWSheadline: HIGH RIP CURRENT RISK IN EFFECT THROUGH TUESDAY MORNING

properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Seattle has issued a Gale Watch...
which is in effect from late tonight through Tuesday afternoon.

* WINDs...Possibly rising to 25 to 35 kt after midnight tonight
into Tuesday morning.
properties.headline: Gale Watch issued September 16 at 3:16AM PDT until September 17 at 5:00PM PDT by NWS Seattle WA
properties.instruction:
A Gale Watch is issued when the risk of gale force winds of 34 to
47 knots has significantly increased, but the specific timing
and/or location is still uncertain. It is intended to provide
additional lead time for mariners who may wish to consider
altering their plans.

properties.description:

* WAVES/SEAS...South winds rising to 30 to 40 knots after
midnight. Combined seas building to 8 to 11 feet.
properties.headline: Gale Warning issued September 16 at 3:16AM PDT until September 17 at 5:00PM PDT by NWS Seattle WA
properties.instruction:
A Gale Warning means winds of 34 to 47 knots are imminent or
occurring. Operating a vessel in gale conditions requires
experience and properly equipped vessels. It is highly
recommended that mariners without the proper experience seek safe
harbor prior to the onset of gale conditions.

properties.description:

Current Risk, which is in effect from 6 pm this evening through
at least Tuesday morning.

* LOCATION...from the North Central to Northeast beaches of
Puerto Rico and Culebra.

* TIMING...from this evening

* IMPACTS...Strong currents that can carry even the strongest of
swimmers out to sea.
properties.headline: Rip Current Statement issued September 16 at 3:25AM AST until September 17 at 6:00AM AST by NWS San Juan PR
properties.instruction:
There is a high risk of rip currents.

Swim near a lifeguard. If caught in a rip current, relax and
float. Don't swim against the current. If able, swim in a
direction following the shoreline. If unable to escape, face the
shore and call or wave for help.

properties.areaDesc: Coastal waters from Cape Blanco OR to Pt. St. George CA out 10 nm; Waters from Cape Blanco OR to Pt. St. George CA from 10 to 60 nm
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Medford has issued a Gale
Warning...which is in effect from 8 AM to 5 PM PDT Tuesday. A
Hazardous Seas Warning has also been issued and is in effect from
8 AM to 5 PM PDT Tuesday. In addition... a Small Craft Advisory
has been issued...which is in effect from 5 AM to 5 PM PDT
Tuesday.

* Winds...South gales 30 to 40 kt with gusts to 50 kt.

* Seas...Steep to very steep and hazardous 8 to 11 ft.

* Areas affected...Conditions hazardous to small craft are
expected north of Gold Beach early Tuesday morning. Then most
areas will be affected by very steep and hazardous seas through
Tuesday afternoon. Gales are expected north of Pistol River and
within 30 nm of shore.

* View the hazard area in detail at
https://www.wrh.noaa.gov/mfr/hazard
properties.headline: Hazardous Seas Warning issued September 16 at 2:24AM PDT until September 17 at 5:00PM PDT by NWS Medford OR
properties.instruction:
A Gale Warning means winds of 34 to 47 knots are imminent or
occurring. Operating a vessel in gale conditions requires
experience and properly equipped vessels. It is highly
recommended that mariners without the proper experience seek safe
harbor prior to the onset of gale conditions.

A Hazardous Seas Warning means very steep and hazardous sea
conditions are imminent or occurring. Recreational boaters should
remain in port, or take shelter until waves subside.  Commercial
vessels should prepare for rough seas and consider remaining in
port or taking shelter in port until hazardous seas subside.

A Small Craft Advisory means that winds and seas will create a
potential hazard to smaller vessels and inexperienced mariners.

properties.description:

Warning...which is in effect from 8 AM to 5 PM PDT Tuesday. A
Hazardous Seas Warning has also been issued and is in effect from
8 AM to 5 PM PDT Tuesday. In addition... a Small Craft Advisory
has been issued...which is in effect from 5 AM to 8 AM PDT
Tuesday.

* Winds...South gales 30 to 40 kt with gusts to 50 kt.

* Seas...Steep to very steep and hazardous 9 to 12 ft.

* Areas affected...All areas will be affected by conditions
hazardous to small craft early Tuesday morning. Then areas
beyond 1 to 2 nm from shore and within 50 nm of shore will be
affected by gales, with very steep and hazardous seas occurring
across all areas through Tuesday afternoon.

* View the hazard area in detail at
https://www.wrh.noaa.gov/mfr/hazard
properties.headline: Small Craft Advisory issued September 16 at 2:24AM PDT until September 17 at 8:00AM PDT by NWS Medford OR
properties.instruction:
A Gale Warning means winds of 34 to 47 knots are imminent or
occurring. Operating a vessel in gale conditions requires
experience and properly equipped vessels. It is highly
recommended that mariners without the proper experience seek safe
harbor prior to the onset of gale conditions.

A Hazardous Seas Warning means very steep and hazardous sea
conditions are imminent or occurring. Recreational boaters should
remain in port, or take shelter until waves subside.  Commercial
vessels should prepare for rough seas and consider remaining in
port or taking shelter in port until hazardous seas subside.

A Small Craft Advisory means that winds and seas will create a
potential hazard to smaller vessels and inexperienced mariners.

properties.description:
...Dense Fog Advisory through 1000 AM...

.Widespread dense fog is expected to develop and overspread the
region through the morning rush hour. Visibilities will be limited
to less than a quarter mile.

The National Weather Service in Raleigh has issued a Dense Fog
Advisory, which is in effect until 10 AM EDT this morning.

* VISIBILITIES...One quarter mile or less, locally a few hundred
feet at times.

* TIMING...The poorest visibilities are expected through 800 AM,
with significant improvement by 1000 AM.

* IMPACTS...Limited visibilities will make travel very difficult.
properties.headline: Dense Fog Advisory issued September 16 at 5:16AM EDT until September 16 at 10:00AM EDT by NWS Raleigh NC
properties.instruction:
A dense fog advisory means visibilities will frequently be
reduced to one quarter mile or less. If driving, slow down, use
low beam headlights, and leave plenty of following distance.
Exercise additional caution at intersections and highway onramps
and offramps where accidents are more likely to occur.

NWSheadline: DENSE FOG ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 10 AM EDT THIS MORNING

properties.areaDesc: Martin; St. Lucie; Indian River
properties.description:
...High Surf Advisory Continues into Tonight...

The National Weather Service in Melbourne has issued a High Rip
Current Risk, which is in effect through this evening.

* TIMING...The highest threat for rip currents will be around the
time of high tide, which is from 7 am this morning through 1 pm
this afternoon. The threat for rip currents will remain high
even late this afternoon due to large breaking waves and a
pronounced longshore current.

* IMPACTS...Rough surf and numerous strong rip currents in the
surf zone will post a threat to swimmers today. Swimmers may
not to enter the water above their knees today. Always swim
within sight of a lifeguard, never swim alone.
properties.headline: Rip Current Statement issued September 16 at 4:18AM EDT until September 16 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Melbourne FL
properties.instruction:
There is a high risk of rip currents.

Rip currents are powerful channels of water flowing quickly away
from shore, which occur most often at low spots or breaks in the
sandbar and in the vicinity of structures such as jetties and
piers. Heed the advice of lifeguards...beach patrol flags and
signs.

Swim near a lifeguard. If caught in a rip current, relax and
float. Don't swim against the current. If able, swim in a
direction following the shoreline. If unable to escape, face the
shore and call or wave for help.

NWSheadline: HIGH RIP CURRENT RISK IN EFFECT THROUGH THIS EVENING

properties.areaDesc: Southern Brevard County; Northern Brevard County; Coastal Volusia
properties.description:
...High Surf Advisory Continues into Tonight...

The National Weather Service in Melbourne has issued a High Rip
Current Risk, which is in effect through this evening.

* WAVES AND SURF...High surf is expected to continue at area
beaches at least through late tonight with breaking waves of 5
to 7 feet. Minor beach erosion is possible around the time of
high tides, which will be around 10 am this morning and 10 pm
tonight.

* TIMING...Surf will continue to build through late tonight.

* IMPACTS...High surf can knock you down and make you susceptible
to being caught in a rip current. There is a high threat of rip
currents.
properties.headline: Rip Current Statement issued September 16 at 4:18AM EDT until September 16 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Melbourne FL
properties.instruction:
A High Surf Advisory means that high surf will affect beaches in
the advisory area...producing localized beach erosion and
dangerous swimming conditions.

Swim near a lifeguard. If caught in a rip current, relax and
float. Don't swim against the current. If able, swim in a
direction following the shoreline. If unable to escape, face the
shore and call or wave for help.

properties.areaDesc: Lower Snake River Plain
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Pocatello has issued a Wind
Advisory, which is in effect from 2 PM this afternoon to 8 PM MDT
this evening.

* IMPACTS/TIMING...Strong south winds will create hazardous
crosswind conditions along east-west routes this afternoon and
early evening. Difficult driving conditions are expected for
high- profile vehicles and vehicles with trailers.

* WINDS...South winds 25 to 35 mph with gusts to 45 mph.

* LOCATIONS...The Lower Snake River Plain, mainly along the
Interstate 86 and Interstate 15 corridors from American Falls to
to Fort Hall.
properties.headline: Wind Advisory issued September 16 at 3:00AM MDT until September 16 at 8:00PM MDT by NWS Pocatello ID
properties.instruction:
A wind advisory means that winds of 30 mph are expected. Gusts
over 45 mph are possible. Winds this strong can make driving
difficult, especially for high profile vehicles. Use extra
caution.

Advisory, which is in effect from 2 PM this afternoon to 8 PM MDT

* IMPACTS/TIMING...Strong south winds will create hazardous
crosswind conditions along east-west routes this afternoon and
early evening. Difficult driving conditions are expected for

* WINDS...South winds 25 to 35 with gusts to 45 mph.

* LOCATIONS...Marsh and Arbon Highlands including the Interstate
15 corridor from Inkom to Downey, and the Eastern Oneida Region
including Malad and Preston.

properties.areaDesc: Death Valley National Park
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Las Vegas has issued a Wind
Advisory, which is in effect from 2 PM this afternoon to 9 PM PDT
this evening.

* WINDS...West winds gusting 40 to 50 mph can be expected for much
of Death Valley National Park. Highest winds can be expected at
the upper elevations.

* TIMING...Winds will increase across early this afternoon then
peak during the late afternoon followed by a gradual decrease
this evening.

* IMPACTS...Wind gusts of 40 to 50 mph will make driving difficult
or hazardous for motorcycles and high profile vehicles and may
create areas of blowing dust.
properties.headline: Wind Advisory issued September 16 at 1:58AM PDT until September 16 at 9:00PM PDT by NWS Las Vegas NV
properties.instruction:
Motorcycle riders and drivers of vans...campers...trailers and
any other high profile vehicle should be alert to the danger of
these strong winds. Use extra caution.

NWSheadline: WIND ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 2 PM THIS AFTERNOON TO 9 PM PDT THIS EVENING

properties.areaDesc: Oahu in Honolulu, HI
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Honolulu has issued a

* Flood advisory for...
The island of Oahu in Honolulu County

* Until 145 AM HST.

* At 1048 PM HST, radar indicated slow-moving heavy showers over the
Koolaus and windward locations, affecting areas from Kaneohe to
Laie. Rain is falling at a rate of 1 to 2 inches per hour. Streams
within the area remain elevated.

* Locations in the advisory include but are not limited to...
Ahuimanu, Hauula, Kaneohe, Kahuku, Waikane, Kaneohe Marine Base,
Laie, Waiahole, Punaluu, Kahaluu, Kaaawa and Kailua.
properties.headline: Flood Advisory issued September 15 at 10:51PM HST until September 16 at 1:45AM HST by NWS Honolulu HI
properties.instruction:
Stay away from streams, drainage ditches and low lying areas prone to
flooding.

Rainfall and runoff will also cause hazardous driving conditions due
to ponding, reduced visibility and poor braking action.

Do not cross fast flowing or rising water in your vehicle, or on
foot. Turn around, don't drown.

properties.description:
...Dense Fog through the Morning Commute...

.Widespread dense fog will reduce visibility to 1/4 mile or less
at times through the morning commute. Fog is expected to dissipate
in most areas by 10 AM. Be alert for sudden changes in visibility
if traveling this morning. Also, be especially cautious near
intersections and when turning onto roadways as other vehicles may
be difficult to see. Slow down and remember to use low-beam
headlights when encountering fog.

The National Weather Service in La Crosse has issued a Dense Fog
Advisory, which is in effect until 10 AM CDT this morning.

* VISIBILITY...1/4 mile or less at times as fog develops quickly
through sunrise.

* IMPACTS...Expect rapid reductions in visibility. Be especially
cautious near intersections and when turning onto roadways.

properties.instruction:

properties.description:

Flagler Beach.

astronomical tide mainly along the St Johns River and
Intracoastal waterways. Above normal water levels may continue
the next few days.

* COASTAL FLOOD IMPACTS...Low lying roads and flood prone areas
may see minor flooding.

* SURF AND RIP CURRENT RISK...Life-threatening rip currents are
expected as strong north to northeast winds continue and high
swells continue. Surf will be rough and dangerous with breaker
heights near 5 to 7 feet. Minor beach erosion is possible.

erosion.

from shore, which occur most often at low spots or breaks in the
sandbar and in the vicinity of structures such as groins, jetties
and piers. Heed the advice of lifeguards and the beach patrol.
Pay attention to flags and posted signs.

The National Weather Service in Miami has issued a High Rip
Current Risk, which is in effect through this evening.

* TIMING...through at least this evening.

* IMPACTS...Life threatening rip currents will pose a hazard to
swimmers. Heed the advice of lifeguards. Swimming is not
recommended.
properties.headline: Rip Current Statement issued September 16 at 3:04AM EDT until September 16 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Miami FL
properties.instruction:
There is a high risk of rip currents.

Rip currents are powerful channels of water flowing quickly away
from shore, which occur most often at low spots or breaks in the
sandbar and in the vicinity of structures such as groins, jetties
and piers. Heed the advice of lifeguards, beach patrol flags and
signs.

Swim near a lifeguard. If caught in a rip current, relax and
float. Don't swim against the current. If able, swim in a
direction following the shoreline. If unable to escape, face the
shore and call or wave for help.

NWSheadline: HIGH RIP CURRENT RISK IN EFFECT THROUGH THIS EVENING

properties.description:
A very wet period is expected with the potential for multiple
atmospheric river events to impact southeast Alaska. The first
event is expected to occur Wednesday into early Thursday with a
second more significant event expected to occur Friday and
Saturday. There is potential for yet another event early next
week. Exact timing and precipitation amounts remain uncertain;
however, the Northeast Gulf Coast is currently the most favored
area for highest precipitation totals. In all of these events,
rainfall has the potential to reach multi inch daily totals. The
potential also exists for significant rises to occur along small
streams and water basins, so continue to monitor the latest
forecasts and statements.
